Hello. My name is Miss Evans. I am one of the Second Grade teachers. This will be my fourth year teaching at Walker!

One of my favorite things about second grade is the Flat Stanley unit. This unit intertwines social studies and language arts. It is fun to read the story and design our very own Flat Stanley to send on an adventure and later present to the class!

Here is a great activity to make and then use outside to get some fresh air. Be sure to show us your photos if you try this activity at home.

Puffy Sidewalk Chalk Paint Ingredients
1 cup flour
1 cup water
1 tablespoon dish soap, any brand
5-10 drops food coloring or washable paint

How to Make Sidewalk Chalk Paint:
In a large mixing bowl stir together the flour and water until there are no lumps.
Stir in the dish soap to the flour mixture.
Add food coloring of your choice until you reach the desired color.
Pour the mixture into a squeeze bottle. (Try an old ketchup bottle or something similar that has been washed thoroughly if you don't have one.)
If you are making multiple colors, make each color in a separate bowl.
Watch the kids enjoy hours of fun with their new sidewalk paint.

Today is Science Friday. Walker has a fun experiment for you to do at home. Email a picture of your project to 6.akozminski@nhaschools.com so we can share your fun science experiment.

The Rubber Egg
1. Place an egg into a tall drinking glass.
2. Pour vinegar into the glass until it is completely covered.
3. Put the glass to the side so nobody drinks it or spills it.
4. Let the egg soak overnight. Make some observations! You should notice a lot of foam and bubbles. When it seems to have slowed, move on to the next step.
5. Rinse the vinegar and foam out with water and then cover the egg again with vinegar.
6. Wait for 6 days. At the end of this time, rinse off the egg and pick it up.

You should notice it feels slightly different than when you started… most noticeably it is missing the shell and has a weird rubbery feel to it. Shake it. Gently squeeze it.

Test out your new creation in the sink by dropping it from a few inches and then some more.

You now have a cool creation that can astound your family.

As we soon expect winter snow, we wanted to remind you of a few rules that will help keep our students safe during arrival and dismissal.

• Walker is a smoke free campus so please refrain from smoking in the parking lot.
• Be aware and in your own lane. Snow piles may close in on the lanes and make it a little tighter.

Thanks for helping us keep our parking lot safe for everyone.

Today is the last day of school before break. Before you know it, every parent will hear the dreaded "I'm bored". Here is a fun craft to help beat the blues.

Kool-Aid Playdough Recipe

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup flour
1/4 cup salt
1 Tbsp. cream of tartar (optional)
1/2 cup warm water
1 pkg. unsweetened Kool-Aid (dry)

DIRECTIONS:
Mix together flour, salt, and cream of tartar.
Mix together warm water and Kool-Aid.
Mix together flour mixture and water mixture. Stir until combined, then knead with hands until flour is absorbed. If dough is sticky, add more flour.

Smells wonderful, is non-toxic, and takes on the color of the Kool-Aid.

We are looking forward to our next community night of learning. Walker Charter Academy will be hosting a Parent Seminar on October 29th at 6:45 p.m. The title of the talk is:
Digital Trends 2019-2020 – Equipping Kids to Thrive in an Increasingly Hostile Online World.

The seminar is being presented by Carol Glanville from “Protect Young Eyes”, an organization located in the Grand Rapids area that presents at hundreds of organizations annually on issues related to smartphone use. Yes, technology is a great thing, if used responsibly! But, digital issues like pornography, predators, sexting, social media, screen time, cyberbullying, anxiety, and depression concern many families. Although many kids use technology well, the Protect Young Eyes team wants to make sure families are prepared to help their children navigate the responsibilities and dangers associated with the digital world.
